{{Other uses}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2012}} A '''late bloomer''' is a person whose talents or capabilities are not visible to others until later than usual.<ref>[http://www.yourdictionary.com/late-bloomer Yourdictionary.com]</ref><ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/late%20bloomer?s=t Dictionary.com]</ref><ref>[http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/american/late-bloomer Collinsdictionary.com]</ref> The term is used metaphorically to describe a child or adolescent who develops slower than others in their age group, but eventually catches up and in some cases overtakes their peers, or an adult whose talent or genius in a particular field only appears later in life than is normal – in some cases only in old age.
This article discusses late-blooming children, adolescents, and adults.
==Children== [[File:Young Thomas Edison.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Thomas Edison]] as a boy]]
"Late Bloomer" is commonly used to refer to young children who develop skills such as language, reading, or social interaction later than others of their age.
There are many theories of the way in which children develop, proposed by authorities such as [[Urie Bronfenbrenner]],<ref>[http://www.news.cornell.edu/stories/Sept05/Bronfenbrenner.ssl.html "Urie Bronfenbrenner, father of Head Start program and pre-eminent 'human ecologist,' dies at age 88"] Cornell University 26 September 2005</ref> [[Jerome Bruner]],<ref>Bruner, J. S. & Goodman, C. C. (1947). Value and need as organizing factors in perception. ''Journal of Abnormal Social Psychology'', 42, 33–44. [http://psychclassics.yorku.ca/Bruner/Value/ Available online at the Classics in the History of Psychology archive]</ref> [[Erik Erikson]], [[Jerome Kagan]], [[Lawrence Kohlberg]], [[Jean Piaget]],<ref>*Piaget, J. (1977). "The essential Piaget" ed by Howard E. Gruber and J. Jacques Voneche Gruber, New York: Basic Books</ref> and [[Lev Vygotsky]]. Although they disagree about how stages of development should be defined, and about the primary influences on development, they agree that a child's development can be measured as a predictable series of advances in physical, intellectual and social skills which almost always occur in the same sequence, although the rate may vary from one child to another.
When a child falls behind their peers at some stage of development, their teacher may perceive that the child is "backward". There is strong evidence that this perception may become self-fulfilling: although the child catches up, the teacher may continue to rate their performance poorly, imposing a long-term handicap.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110716135424/http://www.se.rit.edu/~swami/LearningPapers/alvidrez1999TeacherPerceptions.pdf "Early Teacher Perceptions and Later Student Academic Achievement"] Journal of Educational Psychology, 1999</ref><ref>{{Cite book | last = Heatherton | first = Edited by Todd F. | year = 2003 | title = The social psychology of stigma Chapter 13: Stigma and Self-Fulfilling Prophecies | isbn = 1-57230-942-3 | publisher = Guilford Press | location = New York}}</ref> [[Thomas Edison]]'s mind often wandered and his teacher was overheard calling him "addled." This ended Edison's three months of official schooling. His mother then [[Homeschooling|home schooled]] him.<ref>[http://www.projectshum.org/Edison/ "Thomas Edison biography"] ProjectShum.org. Retrieved 8 January 2008</ref> Edison may have had some form of [[Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder]] (ADHD), which the American Psychiatric Institute says affects about 3 – 5% of children.<ref>[http://ajp.psychiatryonline.org/cgi/content/full/164/6/856 "Why does the worldwide prevalence of childhood attention deficit hyperactivity disorder matter?"] American Psychiatric Association. Retrieved 8 January 2009.</ref>
[[File:Albert Einstein as a child.jpg|thumb|left|200px|[[Albert Einstein]] in 1893 (age 14)]]
A notable example of a child who overcame early developmental problems is [[Albert Einstein]], who suffered from speech difficulties as a young child.<ref>{{cite book | first = Thomas | last = Sowell | title = The Einstein Syndrome: Bright Children Who Talk Late | pages = 89–150 | publisher = [[Basic Books]] | year = 2001 | isbn= 0-465-08140-1 }}</ref> Other late-talking children who became highly-successful engineers, mathematicians, and scientists include the physicists [[Richard Feynman]]<ref name="turnbull">{{cite web|url=http://turnbull.mcs.st-and.ac.uk/~history/Biographies/Feynman.html|title=Richard Phillips Feynman|publisher=University of St. Andrews|author1=J.J. O'Connor |author2=E.F. Robertson |lastauthoramp=yes |date=August 2002| accessdate =9 November 2006}}</ref> and [[Edward Teller]].<ref>Stanley A. Blumberg and Louis G. Panos. ''Edward Teller: giant of the golden age of physics; a biography'' (Scribner's, 1990)</ref> Neuroscientist [[Steven Pinker]] postulates that a certain form of [[language delay]] may in fact be associated with exceptional and innate-analytical prowess in some individuals.<ref>{{cite web|author=Pinker, Steven |title=His Brain Measured Up |work=Harvard.edu |url=http://pinker.wjh.harvard.edu/articles/media/1999_06_24_newyorktimes.html |accessdate=December 4, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061211085927/http://pinker.wjh.harvard.edu/articles/media/1999_06_24_newyorktimes.html |archivedate=11 December 2006 |df= }}</ref>
[[Dyslexia]] is a learning disability that may affect 3–10% of children. It is thought to be the result of a genetically inherited neurological difference from "normal" children, and has been diagnosed in people of all levels of intelligence.<ref name=conversation>{{cite web|url=http://www.schwablearning.org/articles.aspx?r=718 |title=A Conversation with Sally Shaywitz, M.D., author of Overcoming Dyslexia |accessdate=21 April 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080229012841/http://www.schwablearning.org/articles.aspx?r=718 |archivedate=29 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Studies indicate that 20% to 35% of U.S. and British entrepreneurs have the condition: by definition, late bloomers. Researchers theorise that dyslexic entrepreneurs may attain success by delegating responsibilities and excelling at verbal communication.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tracing Business Acumen to Dyslexia|date=6 December 2007|author=Brent Bowers|work=New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/06/business/06dyslexia.html}}</ref> [[Richard Branson]], known for his [[Virgin Group|Virgin]] brand of over 360 companies is a notable example,<ref>Branson, Richard. ''Losing My Virginity: How I've Survived, Had Fun, And Made a Fortune Doing Business My Way'', 1999, Three Rivers Press. {{ISBN|0-8129-3229-3}}</ref> as is [[Charles R. Schwab]] the founder and CEO of the [[Charles Schwab Corporation]].<ref>[http://www.stanfordalumni.org/news/magazine/1999/marapr/articles/schwab.html Charles Schwab's Secret Struggle] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070815082613/http://www.stanfordalumni.org/news/magazine/1999/marapr/articles/schwab.html |date=15 August 2007 }} Stanford Magazine: March/April 1999. Retrieved 7 January 2008</ref> [[Pablo Picasso]], [[Tom Cruise]], and [[Whoopi Goldberg]] are other examples of dyslexics, considered "slow" as children.<ref>[http://www.dyslexiaonline.com/famous/famous.htm "Dyslexic? You're not alone..."] dyslexiaonline.com. Retrieved 7 January 2009.</ref>
The [[autism spectrum]] of psychological conditions affects about 0.6% of children, characterized by widespread abnormalities of social interactions and communication, severely-restricted interests, and highly-repetitive behavior.<ref>{{cite book |chapterurl=http://www.who.int/classifications/apps/icd/icd10online/?gf80.htm+f840 |year=2006 |accessdate=25 June 2007 |title= International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems |edition= 10th ed. ([[ICD-10]]) |author= [[World Health Organization]] |chapter= F84. Pervasive developmental disorders}}</ref> [[List of people on the autistic spectrum|Notable individuals with autism spectrum disorders]] include [[Tim Page (music critic)|Tim Page]], a [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning critic and author<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2007/08/20/070820fa_fact_page?printable=true|author=Page, Tim|work=The New Yorker|title=Parallel Play: A lifetime of restless isolation explained|date=20 August 2007|accessdate=8 November 2007}}</ref> and [[Vernon L. Smith]], a [[Nobel Laureate]] in economics.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mild autism has 'selective advantages'|publisher=MSNBC|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/7030731/|author=Herera, Sue|date=25 February 2005|accessdate=8 November 2007}}</ref>
==Adolescents== [[File:William Butler Yeats by John Butler Yeats 1900.jpg|thumb|right|Portrait of young William Butler Yeats by his father, John Butler Yeats]] During adolescence a child goes through physical and [[Adolescent psychology|mental]] changes that lead to them becoming an adult. Adolescence is usually considered to start with the first stages of [[puberty]] and to continue until physical growth is complete, although the [[World Health Organization]] defines adolescence simply as the period between ages 10 and 20. There is a wide range of normal ages, but generally girls begin the process of puberty between the ages of 9 to 14, reaching adult height and reproductive maturity within 4 years, while boys usually start between the ages of 10 to 17, and continue to grow for about 6 years after the first visible pubertal changes.<ref>{{cite book | last = Marshall | first = William A. |author2=Tanner, JM | editor = Falkner F |editor2=Tanner JM, eds. | title = Human Growth: A Comprehensive Treatise | edition = 2nd | year = 1986 | publisher = Plenum Press | location = New York | isbn=0-306-41952-1 | pages = 171–209 | chapter =Chapter 8: Puberty}}</ref> Adolescence is often a period of turbulent emotions and [[mood swings]] combined with rapid, intellectual development.<ref name=Viner_2005>{{cite journal | last = Viner | first = Russell |author2=Christie, Deborah | title = Adolescent development | journal = British Medical Journal | volume = 330 | issue = 7486| pages = 301–304 | date = 5 February 2005 | url = http://www.bmj.com/cgi/content/full/330/7486/301 | doi = 10.1136/bmj.330.7486.301 | id = | accessdate =20 June 2007 | pmid = 15695279 | pmc = 548185 }}</ref>
"Late bloomer" can refer to children who suffer from [[delayed puberty]], who are late in reaching their full height. [[W. B. Yeats]] (age 30),<ref>Foster, R. F. (1997). ''W. B. Yeats: A Life, Vol. I: The Apprentice Mage''. New York: [[Oxford University Press|Oxford UP]]. {{ISBN|0-19-288085-3}}</ref> [[Pierre Trudeau]] (age at least 28),<ref>''Memoirs'', by Pierre Elliott Trudeau, Toronto 1993, [[McClelland & Stewart]] publishers.</ref> [[Mark Twain]] (age 34), and [[Johann von Goethe]] (age 39) are all "late bloomers" in this last sense.
In most [[public education]]al systems, children and adolescents of the same age are put in the same classes. Because of the wide variance in the onset of adolescence, this means that one class may include individuals who have not yet started puberty, others who are [[Sexual maturity|sexually mature]] but not fully grown and yet others who are effectively adult. During this period, there is a high risk of an adolescent dropping out of formal education (due most commonly to laziness, intellectual boredom, [[bullying]], or rebellion) without having achieved their full learning potential.<ref>[http://www.ericdigests.org/1996-1/dropout.htm "Dropout Intervention and Language Minority Youth"] ERIC Digest. Retrieved 5 January 2009</ref> The term "late-bloomer" may refer to such an individual who develops serious intellectual interests in their 20s or 30s and enrols in college, where he or she performs particularly well and subsequently establishes a professional career.
==Adults==
A late blooming adult is a person who does not discover their talents and abilities until later than normally expected. In certain cases retirement may lead to this discovery.
Although there is a common perception that intellectual development peaks in a young adult and then slowly declines with increasing age, this may be simplistic. Although the ability to form new memories and concepts may indeed diminish, the older person has the advantage of accumulated knowledge, associations between concepts, and mental techniques that may give them an advantage in some fields.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1147163-1,00.html "The Surprising Power of the Aging Brain"] ''Time'' magazine</ref>
Some notable examples of late bloomers in different fields follow.
===Acting=== It was common for many actors to not get their big 'break' into the [[film industry]] until their late twenties or well into their thirties. [[Meryl Streep]] did not graduate [[Yale School of Drama]] until the age of twenty seven. The actor [[Alan Rickman]] did not begin his career until he was twenty eight, having operated a graphic-design company before then. He did not get his first real break into theatre until he was in his forties. [[Danny Aiello]] did not start acting until he was forty. [[Peg Phillips]] might be one of the best examples as she first pursued acting as a professional after her retirement from accounting; she started acting professionally in her late sixties.<ref>[http://www.seattlepi.com/local/95227_phillips12.shtml "Actress realized her dream on 'Northern Exposure'"] SEATTLE POST-INTELLIGENCER 12 November 2002. Retrieved 3 January 2009</ref> Although not a noteworthy actress, [[Clara Peller]] might be noted for having an even later start in entertainment, in her eighties.<ref>[http://www.tvacres.com/admascots_clarapeller.htm "Advertising Mascots – People"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130204225535/http://www.tvacres.com/admascots_clarapeller.htm |date=4 February 2013 }} TV Acres. Retrieved 3 January 2008</ref> [[Richard Farnsworth]] became an actor after forty years as a stunt man, although he had had a few small uncredited roles when younger.<ref>[http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,278109,00.html "Cowboy's Way – The straight story on the life and death of Oscar nominee Richard Farnsworth"] Entertainment Weekly Obituary. Retrieved 5 January 2008</ref> [[Rodney Dangerfield]] was an actor/comedian who did not really start until he was forty two. He had done clubs when he was younger, but stopped in order to work as a salesman.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/6187136/|title=Rodney Dangerfield dead at 82|author=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=MSNBC|date=7 October 2004|accessdate=3 January 2009}}</ref> [[Zelda Rubinstein]] was forty eight before she had her first role, a minor part in ''[[Under the Rainbow]]'', but is more known for her "debut" in the [[Poltergeist (film series)|''Poltergeist'' film series]] starting the following year. Chicago native, [[Chi McBride]], best known for the role as the principal in the series ''Boston Public'', only got into acting when he was thirty one.<ref>{{IMDb name|id=0564277|name=Chi McBride}}</ref> [[Danny Glover]] had a brief stint in the career of politics before he had involved himself in acting at twenty eight.<ref>{{IMDb name|id=0000418|name=Danny Glover}}</ref> BAFTA winning British actress [[Liz Smith (actress)|Liz Smith]] did not become a professional actress until the age of fifty. [[Kathryn Joosten]] also got a late start, beginning acting at age forty two in community theater.<ref>{{IMDb name|0429760|name=Kathryn Joosten}}</ref> Television star [[Judd Hirsch]] from ''Taxi'' and character actor [[Bill Cobbs]] became active at the age of thirty six. [[George Wendt]] who played Norm on ''Cheers'' became active at the age of thirty two. [[Brian Dennehy]] had dreams of stage and screen at an early age, but chose to first pursue other interests such as service in the U.S. Marine Corps prior to becoming active at the age of thirty eight. Irish actor [[Brendan Gleeson]], who appeared as [[Mad Eye Moody]] in the ''[[Harry Potter]]'' films and alongside [[Colin Farrell]] in ''[[In Bruges]]'', started acting professionally at thirty four, having previous work as a school teacher. The Indian (Bengali) actor [[Paran Bandopadhyay]] is another late bloomer, who started his acting career in television and films at the age of sixty, after retiring from his government job. [[Jerry Doyle]], of ''[[Babylon 5]]'' fame, did not start acting until he was thirty six after working as a stockbroker and pilot. [[Sylvester Stallone]] was thirty when he wrote and starred in the first ''[[Rocky]]''. All throughout his life, he has pushed his body through rigorous training routines for his film roles. Most notably at age forty three, he developed his now-famous ''Rambo 3'' physique which got him named as "body of the '80s". The veteran Indian (Malayalam) actor [[Sathyan (actor)|Sathyan]] started his career at the age of forty, after resigning from Police Service. He later came to be known as one of the greatest actors ever in Malayalam film industry.
===Art=== [[File:Grandma Moses NYWTS.jpg|thumb|right|Grandma Moses]]
In art "late bloomers" are most often associated with [[naïve art]]. This term is used for untrained artists so fits those who start late in life without artistic training. Hence the classic late bloomer is [[Grandma Moses]] whose painting career began in her seventies after abandoning a career in embroidery because of arthritis.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/learning/general/onthisday/bday/0907.html Grandma Moses Obituary] New York Times. 14 December 1961</ref> An even older example is [[Bill Traylor]] who started drawing at age 83.<ref>[http://www.petulloartcollection.com/artistprofile.asp?refArtistID=47 "Bill Traylor short biography"] Anthony Petullo Collection of Self-Taught and Outsider Art. Retrieved 3 January 2009</ref> Another painter who started late in life is [[Alfred Wallis]], who began painting after his wife's death in his 60s.<ref>[http://www.alfredwallis.org.uk The Life & Work of Alfred Wallis – St Ives Artist & Mariner] Retrieved 3 January 2009</ref> [[Mary Delany]] produced her "paper mosaiks [sic]" from the age of 71 to 88.<ref>Laird, Mark and Weisberg-Roberts, Alicia (Ed.). Mrs. Delany & Her Circle (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2009). {{ISBN|978-0-300-14279-2}}, p. 36</ref> Then there is [[Carmen Herrera]], who did have artistic training, but who sold her first artwork in 2004 when she was 89 years old, after six decades of private painting.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/20/arts/design/20herrera.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 ''The New York Times'']</ref>
===Business=== In business [[Irene Wells Pennington]] became best known in her nineties when she helped straighten out irregularities in her husband's oil business after he went senile in his own 90s.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/finance/lists/54/1999/LIR.jhtml?passListId=54&passYear=1999&passListType=Person&uniqueId=2646&datatype=Person Irene Pennington on 1999 Forbes 400 (oldest member of the list)] Forbes. Retrieved 3 January 2009</ref> [[Colonel Sanders]] began his franchise in his sixties and can also be deemed a late in life financial success.<ref>{{cite web|date=29 December 1980 | accessdate=3 January 2009 |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,922291,00.html |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |title=Milestones – Colonel Sanders}}</ref> In his mid-50s [[Taikichiro Mori]] founded the business that made him, for a year or two, the richest man in the world. He came from a merchant family, but had been a business professor before his 50s.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/asia/covers/501040223/mori.html "The Families that Own Asia"] ''Time'' magazine 16 February 2004. Retrieved 3 January 2009</ref>
===Dance===
Japanese dancer and choreographer [[Kazuo Ohno]] did not undertake formal dance lessons until his late twenties and was 43 years old when he performed his first recital at Kanda Kyoritsu Hall in Tokyo in 1949. A decade later, he and colleague [[Tatsumi Hijikata]] would achieve worldwide acclaim as the nucleus of the [[Butoh]] dance movement.<ref>[http://www.kazuoohnodancestudio.com/english/kazuo_desc/ "Kazuo Ohno Biography"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090225114259/http://www.kazuoohnodancestudio.com/english/kazuo_desc/ |date=25 February 2009 }} Kazuo Ohno Dance Studio Official Website. Retrieved 20 January 2009</ref> [[Martha Graham]] dancer David Zurak took his first dance class at the age of 23 and built a successful career in New York City.
===Games and sports===
In professional sports, an athlete's career usually ends in the mid-to-late 30s, so a player who breaks through in their late 20s/early 30s would be considered a late bloomer. One such example is [[Kurt Warner]], who entered the [[National Football League|NFL]] at age 28, and went on to become a two-time MVP and [[Super Bowl]] champion.<ref>[https://archive.is/20120919024221/http://www.sportsline.com/nfl/story/11103260 "In midst of MVP-type season, Warner is name for Fame"] CBS Sports. Retrieved 7 January 2009.</ref> Baseball pitcher [[Randy Johnson]], who made his [[Major League Baseball|Major League]] debut at 25, but didn't reach superstar status until he was 30, might also be considered a late bloomer,<ref>[http://www.jockbio.com/Bios/RJohnson/RJohnson_bio.html "Randy Johnson – Bio"] jockbio.com. Retrieved 7 January 2009.</ref> Former NBA star, [[Hakeem Olajuwon]] did not touch a basketball until he was 15, but his athleticism and fundamentals from the sports, football and handball, helped him advance as one of the greatest bigmen to ever play in the NBA.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B06E3DD153AF93BA35755C0A962958260 "Feet of Dancer, Touch of Surgeon, and a Shot, Too"] ''New York Times''. Retrieved 7 January 2009.</ref>
[[File:Oscar Swahn 1912 Olympic games.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Oscar Swahn at the 1912 Olympic Games, aged 64]]
In shooting there have been two figures of note whose accomplishments occurred in their sixties or later. [[Joshua Millner]] of Britain was 61 when he won his Olympic gold medal in [[Shooting at the 1908 Summer Olympics#Free rifle, 1,000 yards|Free rifle, 1,000 yards]].<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2000/0916/00091600153.html "Irish rifleman's record unlikely to be matched"] Irish Times. Retrieved 5 January 2009</ref> Swedish marksman [[Oscar Swahn]] won two Olympic gold medals at the age of 60 and one at the age of 64. He won his last medal, silver, at 72 making him the oldest medalist.<ref>[http://www.databaseolympics.com/players/playerpage.htm?ilkid=SWAHNOSC01 "Oscar Swain"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080930050855/http://www.databaseolympics.com/players/playerpage.htm?ilkid=SWAHNOSC01 |date=30 September 2008 }} databaseOlympics.com. Retrieved 5 January 2009</ref> In athletics [[Philip Rabinowitz (runner)|Philip Rabinowitz]] set a sprinting record for centenarians.<ref>[http://www.seniorjournal.com/NEWS/Sports/4-07-10Fastest.htm "Philip Rabinowitz is Officially the World’s Fastest Centenarian"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012002346/http://www.seniorjournal.com/NEWS/Sports/4-07-10Fastest.htm |date=12 October 2008 }} SENIOR JOURNAL.COM. Retrieved 5 January 2009</ref>
[[Jonah Barrington (squash player)|Jonah Barrington]], a squash player, overcame alcoholism to later become a 6 times British Open Squash champion, and was regarded as one of the fittest men on the planet.<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20021207/ai_n12655923 "SQUASH: WHATEVER HAPPENED TO JONAH BARRINGTON?"] ''The Independent''. Retrieved 7 January 2009.</ref>
Heavyweight champions [[Ken Norton]] and [[Rocky Marciano]] did not take up [[boxing]] until their twenties, but both enjoyed successful careers at the highest level of competition.
Baseball player [[Josh Hamilton]], a former number one overall draft pick, did not make his major league debut until the age of 26 due to years of serious drug and alcohol abuse. He has since been an all star several times and won the 2010 American League MVP award.<ref>[http://sports.espn.go.com/dallas/mlb/news/story?id=5841798 "Josh Hamilton AL MVP"] "ESPN". Retrieved 25 September 2011.</ref>
Football player [[Didier Drogba]] did not sign a professional contract with a club until the age of 21.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.askmen.com/celebs/men/celeb_profiles_sports/10_didier_drogba.html |title=Didier Drogba |publisher=[[AskMen]] |accessdate=15 August 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714194729/http://www.askmen.com/celebs/men/celeb_profiles_sports/10_didier_drogba.html |archive-date=14 July 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> It was not until the age of 26 when he joined [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] when he showed his real talent as a world-class footballer. Drogba scored the equaliser, and then the winning penalty, in the [[2012 UEFA Champions League Final|2012 UEFA Champions League final]] aged 34.
Indian hockey legend [[Dhyan Chand]] did not play any hockey in his life till he joined the Indian Army.
Cricketer [[Dirk Nannes]] who once was played for [[Delhi Daredevils]] ahead of the great fast bowler [[Glenn McGrath]] made his first class debut at 29.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/australia/content/player/6981.html|title=Dirk Nannes|work=Cricinfo|accessdate=29 November 2014}}</ref>
[[Tim Thomas (ice hockey)|Tim Thomas]], an American professional ice hockey goaltender played for several years in the minor leagues and Europe, before making it to the NHL at age 28, with the Boston Bruins. He finally emerged as the Bruins' starting goaltender at age 32. Thomas is a two-time winner of the Vezina Trophy (2009 and 2011) as the league's best goaltender, and was a member of Team USA in the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver. Thomas won the Conn Smythe Trophy as the most valuable player in the 2011 Stanley Cup playoffs. He became the oldest player in league history to win the Conn Smythe at age 37.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/player.htm?id=8460703&view=allstar|title=Tim Thomas|publisher=|accessdate=29 November 2014}}</ref>
For professional [[tennis]], [[Angelique Kerber]], [[Li Na]], [[Stan Wawrinka]], [[Francesca Schiavone]], [[Flavia Pennetta]], [[Jana Novotna]], [[Goran Ivanišević]] and [[Andrés Gómez]] are famous late bloomers who won their first [[Grand Slam (Tennis)|Grand Slam]] Singles titles after age 28.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usopen.org/en_US/news/articles/2016-09-10/angie_the_late_bloomer.html|title=Angie the late bloomer|work=USOpen.org|accessdate=15 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2663528-how-late-bloomer-stan-wawrinka-redefined-his-career|title=How Late Bloomer Stan Wawrinka|work=bleacherreport.com|accessdate=15 September 2016}}</ref>
===Mathematics=== [[George Green (mathematician)|George Green]], working as a miller and with no formal education in mathematics, published his famous ''[[An Essay on the Application of Mathematical Analysis to the Theories of Electricity and Magnetism]]'' in 1828, at the age of 35.<ref>[http://www.math.washington.edu/~morrow/334_13/green.pdf Math.washington.edu]</ref>
[[Alexandre-Théophile Vandermonde]] started to study mathematics at 35, and began to publish in this field the same year.
[[Eugène Ehrhart]] started publishing in mathematics in his 40s, and finished his PhD thesis at the age of 60.
[[Marjorie Rice]], an amateur mathematician with no formal education in mathematics beyond high school, did not begin studying [[tessellations]] until December 1975; as she was born in 1923, this means she was either 51 or 52 when she began, depending on her birthday.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xrnuPISI2q0C&pg=PA765&dq=marjorie+rice+born+1923&hl=en&sa=X&ei=N__LU6KfGoiuyASBvIHgBA&ved=0CDIQ6wEwAA#v=onepage&q=marjorie%20rice%20born%201923&f=false|title=For All Practical Purposes|publisher=|accessdate=29 November 2014}}</ref><ref name="chronicle.augusta.com">[http://chronicle.augusta.com/stories/1998/03/29/tec_225132.shtml Augusta.com]</ref> She developed her own system of [[Mathematical notation|notation]] and used it to discover three new types of [[Pentagon tiling|tessellating pentagons]] and over sixty distinct tessellations by pentagons by 1977.<ref name="chronicle.augusta.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://britton.disted.camosun.bc.ca/jbperplex.htm|title=Perplexing Pentagons|publisher=|accessdate=29 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160813111016/http://britton.disted.camosun.bc.ca/jbperplex.htm|archivedate=13 August 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
[[Caspar Wessel]] published his only mathematics paper at the age of 54.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www-history.mcs.st-and.ac.uk/Biographies/Wessel.html|title=Wessel biography|publisher=|accessdate=29 November 2014}}</ref><ref>[http://www.channel4.com/news/stop-the-brain-drain-how-to-work-your-greatest-muscle Channel4.com]</ref>
[[Roger Apéry]] proved [[Apéry's theorem]] at the age of 63.
===Music===
Musical ability is inherent in almost all people, to a greater or lesser extent.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20040615022738/http://www.aruffo.com/eartraining/copp.htm "Musical Ability"] Evelyn Fletcher Copp. Originally published in The Journal of Heredity, Volume 7, pages 297–305, July 1916.</ref> However, those who develop it to a high level are generally encouraged to play an instrument or to sing at an early age. Late bloomers in music are generally composers or artists who became prominent later in life, but had displayed musical ability much earlier.<ref>[http://www.zainea.com/ability.htm "Musical ability by John Sloboda"] ESR. Retrieved 6 January 2009.</ref>
[[Anton Bruckner]] is an example of a musical late bloomer. Although he played church organ some in his twenties he did not become a composer until his 40s.<ref>[http://homepage.mac.com/jgreshes/mahler/brucknerbio.html The life of Anton Bruckner] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090412040841/http://homepage.mac.com/jgreshes/mahler/brucknerbio.html |date=12 April 2009 }} American Bruckner Society, 1940. Retrieved 3 January 2009</ref> Singer [[K. T. Oslin]] released her first album at age 47 which was a major [[country music]] success.<ref>[http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/oslin_k_t_/bio.jhtml "K.T. Oslin – Biography"] CMT.com. Retrieved 3 January 2009</ref> [[Al Jarreau]] is also an example, who released his first album at age 35.<ref>[http://www.starpulse.com/Music/Jarreau,_Al/Biography/ "Al Jarreau Biography"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821053458/http://www.starpulse.com/Music/Jarreau%2C_Al/Biography/ |date=21 August 2008 }} Starpulse. Retrieved 6 January 2009.</ref> AERIA Recording Artist Colie Brice released his 10th solo album Late Bloomer at 39. [[Elliott Carter]] did not achieve compositional maturity until his Cello Sonata (1948), when he was 40. [[César Franck]] and [[Leoš Janáček]] also matured late as composers: Franck at 56, with his ''Symphony no. 1 in D''; and Janáček at 50, with ''Jenůfa"'' (1904). [[Iannis Xenakis]] did not even begin studying composition until 30, with Messiaen. [[Leonard Cohen]] did not release his first album until he was 32 years old. Malayalam singer [[Chandralekha (singer)|Chandralekha]] did not start her singing career until the age of 35, when she was shot to fame by a YouTube video featuring her.
===Filmmaking=== [[File:Manuel de Oliveira répondant à Antonio Tabucchi (2008.07.03)-Romanceor.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Manoel de Oliveira]]
Though many filmmakers begin directing in their late 20s or early 30s, many of the most notable directors in film history waited until their mid-to-late-30s to direct their first feature. These directors include [[Nicholas Ray]], [[Alain Resnais]], [[Edward Yang]], [[Michael Mann (director)|Michael Mann]], [[Frank Tashlin]], [[Robert Aldrich]], [[Satyajit Ray]], [[Anthony Mann]], [[Terry Gilliam]], [[Jerry Lewis]], [[Tsai Ming-liang]], [[Don Siegel]], [[Melvin Van Peebles]], [[Gaspar Noé]], [[Lloyd Bacon]], [[Alexander Kluge]], [[Mrinal Sen]], [[Jean-Marie Straub]], [[Ida Lupino]], [[Sam Mendes]], [[Alexander Payne]], [[Ang Lee]] and [[Jacques Rivette]]. [[David Mamet]] directed his first feature at 40, having already found success and been awarded a [[Pulitzer Prize]] as a playwright. [[Éric Rohmer]] directed his first feature film at 39, though he didn't become a full-time filmmaker until he was in his late 40s.
Many notable directors started even later: [[Robert Bresson]], [[Jacques Tati]], and [[Takeshi Kitano]] directed their first features at 42; [[Maurice Pialat]] at 43; [[Michael Haneke]] at 47; [[Jim Sheridan]] at 40; and his peer and collaborator [[Terry George]] at 46. [[Yevgeni Bauer]] at 48. [[Clint Eastwood]], the oldest person to win the [[Academy Award for Best Director]], directed his first film at 41.
One of the most shining examples of late bloomers in filmmaking is the Portuguese director [[Manoel de Oliveira]]. Born in 1908, he worked sporadically in filmmaking from the 1930s. He completed his first feature film in 1941 called ''Aniki-Bobo''. Due to circumstances beyond his control (difficulty in financing, having to deal with his family's business), he did not complete his second feature film until 1971 (when he turned 63). 2 years later, he completed his third feature film, ''Benilde or the Virgin Mother'' (1973). Five years later, he made his breakthrough film (originally commissioned by Portuguese TV) called ''Doomed Love''. After his critically acclaimed film ''Francisca'' (1981), he became a full-time filmmaker (at the age of 73).<ref>[http://www.euronews.net/en/article/12/12/2008/portugals-oliveira-still-making-films-at-100 Portugal’s Oliveira – still making films at 100!] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116202228/http://www.euronews.net/en/article/12/12/2008/portugals-oliveira-still-making-films-at-100/ |date=16 January 2009 }} Euronews 12 December 2008. Retrieved 5 January 2009</ref>
===Politics=== [[File:Churchill HU 90973.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Winston Churchill]], failed thrice at high school.]] It is common for politicians to achieve prominence late in life, often after a career in business, law or academia. For example, in the [[111th United States Congress#Members|United States Congress]] of January 2009, of 540 elected officials, 215 had worked in the legal profession, and 189 had worked in private sector business. The average age of senators was 62.<ref>[http://www.thisnation.com/congress-facts.html "The United States Congress Quick Facts"] ThisNation.com. Retrieved 6 January 2009.</ref> Also, [[Donald Trump]] was the first U.S. President to reach the age of seventy prior to his election to the presidency and first to reach seventy years of age before entering office,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kurtzleben|first1=Danielle|title=It's Trump's Birthday. If He Wins, He'd Be The Oldest President Ever To Take Office|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/06/14/481991965/its-trumps-birthday-if-he-wins-hed-be-the-oldest-president-ever-to-take-office|accessdate=8 December 2016|work=[[NPR]]|date=14 June 2016}}</ref> as well as the first U.S. President to assume the office without any prior military or political experience.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Yomtov|first1=Jesse|title=Where Trump ranks among least experienced presidents|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2016/11/08/donald-trump-experience-president/93504134/|accessdate=14 February 2017|work=[[USA Today]]|date=8 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Montanaro|first1=Domenico|title=Trump's First 100 Days: An 'Entry-Level' Presidency|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/04/23/525111191/trump-s-first-100-days-an-entry-level-presidency|accessdate=11 July 2017|work=[[NPR]]|date=23 April 2017}}</ref>
Some highly successful politicians come from more unusual backgrounds.
[[Václav Havel]], born in 1936, was a playwright and writer with an interest in human rights. He became the voice of the opposition in [[Czechoslovakia]] in the 1980s and President of Czechoslovakia at age 53 after the collapse of the communist regime in 1989.<ref>Kriseová, Eda. ''Václav Havel''. Trans. Caleb Crain. New York: [[St. Martin's Press]], 1993. {{ISBN|0-312-10317-4}}</ref> [[Ronald Reagan]], a former actor, union leader, and corporate spokesman, was first elected to public office at 55 when he became [[Governor of California]] and remains the oldest man to have served as U.S. President. [[Melchora Aquino]] was an uneducated [[Filipino people|Filipino]] peasant woman, the mother of six children, who became an activist in the fight to gain independence from Spain. Known as the Grand Woman of the revolution, she was 84 when the [[Philippine Revolution]] broke out in 1896.<ref>[http://filipino.biz.ph/history/sora.html "Hero of the Philippine Revolution – Melchora Aquino"] Filipino.biz.ph. Retrieved 6 January 2009.</ref> [[Silas C. Swallow]] was a minister who became a [[Prohibition Party]] activist in his sixties.<ref>{{Find a Grave|10942345|accessdate=17 October 2010}}</ref> [[Marjory Stoneman Douglas]]'s career might also fit. Her first environmental work of note occurred when she was almost 60, at 78 she founded "Friends of the Everglades", and she continued until she was over age 100.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E07EEDA143FF930A35752C0A96F958260 "Marjory Stoneman Douglas; Don't Mess With Her Wetlands"] ''New York Times''. Retrieved 6 January 2009.</ref>
===Religion=== [[File:Swami Prabhupada.jpg|thumb|right|A. C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada]]
The great proponent of [[Gaudiya Vaishnavism]] [[A. C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada]] founded the [[International Society for Krishna Consciousness]], or the Hare Krishna movement, in 1966 at the age of 70. Within the final twenty years of his life Prabhupada translated over sixty volumes of classic [[Vedas|Vedic scriptures]] (such as the [[Bhagavad Gita]] and [[Bhagavata Purana]]) into the English language.<ref>{{Cite book| last=Goswami| first=Satsvarupa dasa| year=1984| edition=abr| authorlink = Satsvarupa dasa Goswami| title=Prabhupada: he built a house in which the whole world can live| publisher=Bhaktivedanta Book Trust| place = | location=Los Angeles| isbn=0-89213-133-0}}</ref>
===Writing=== Many writers have published their first major work late in life. [[Mary Wesley]] might be a classic example. She wrote two children's books in her late fifties, but her writing career did not gain note until her first novel at 70, written after the death of her husband.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/arts/2617393.stm "Author Mary Wesley dies"] BBC News. Retrieved 6 January 2009.</ref> At the age of 74, [[Norman Maclean]] published his first and only novel, the 1976 best-selling book ''[[A River Runs Through It (novel)|A River Runs Through It]]'', which fictionalizes Maclean's memories of the early twentieth century in Montana.<ref>[http://www.press.uchicago.edu/books/maclean/index.html Norman Maclean]</ref> [[Harriet Doerr]] published her first novel at age 74, and went on to great praise.<ref>[http://www.stanfordalumni.org/news/magazine/1997/novdec/articles/doerr.html 1997 "Late Bloomer: interview with Harriet Doerr"] ''Stanford Magazine''. Retrieved 6 January 2009.</ref> A possibly more well-known example might be [[Laura Ingalls Wilder]]. She became a columnist in her forties, but did not publish her first novel in the [[Little House on the Prairie|''Little House'' series]] of children's books until her sixties.<ref>[http://www.liwfrontiergirl.com/ "Laura Ingalls Wilder, Frontier Girl"] Retrieved 6 January 2009.</ref> [[Charles Bukowski]] wrote his first novel in 1971, when he was 51 years old.<ref>http://www.avclub.com/article/ipost-officei-by-charles-bukowski-60468/ "Post Office by Charles Bukowski by Kyle Ryan" Retrieved 28 December 2015</ref>
Memoirist and novelist [[Flora Thompson]] was first published in her thirties but is most famous for the semi-autobiographical ''[[Lark Rise to Candleford]]'' trilogy, the first volume of which was published when she was 63. [[Frank McCourt]] didn't publish his first book ''[[Angela's Ashes]]'', which he later won the Pulitzer Prize for, until he was 66. Children's author [[Mary Alice Fontenot]] wrote her first book at 51 and wrote almost thirty additional books, publishing multiple volumes in her eighties and nineties.<ref>[http://www.pelicanpub.com/Biog.asp?artist=Mary%20Alice%20Fontenot "Mary Alice Fontenot Biography"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928144145/http://www.pelicanpub.com/Biog.asp?artist=Mary%20Alice%20Fontenot |date=28 September 2007 }} Pelican Press. Retrieved 6 January 2009.</ref> [[Kenneth Grahame]] was born in 1859 and joined the [[Bank of England]] in 1879, rising through the ranks to become its secretary. Although he had written various short stories while working at the bank, it was only after his retirement in 1908 that he published his masterpiece and final work ''[[The Wind in the Willows]]''.<ref name=Prince1994>{{Cite book | last = Prince | first = Alison | year = 1994 | title = Kenneth Grahame: an innocent in the Wild Wood | isbn = 978-0-85031-829-6 | publisher = Allison & Busby | location = London}}</ref> [[Penelope Fitzgerald]] launched her literary career in 1975, at the age of 58, when she published a biography of the Pre-Raphaelite artist Edward Burne-Jones. She won the Booker Prize for 1979 with ''Offshore'', and in 2012, ''The Observer'' named her final novel, ''The Blue Flower'', as one of "the ten best historical novels".
[[Richard Adams (author)|Richard Adams's]] first novel, the bestseller ''[[Watership Down]]'', was published when he was in his fifties. The [[Marquis de Sade]] published his first novel, ''[[Justine (Sade novel)|Justine]]'', after turning 51. [[Raymond Chandler]] published his first short story at 45, and his first novel, ''[[The Big Sleep]]'' at 51. [[Paul Torday]] published his debut novel ''[[Salmon Fishing in the Yemen (novel)|Salmon Fishing in the Yemen]]'' at the age of 59, after a career in the engineering industry. [[Jean Rhys]] is best known for her novel ''[[Wide Sargasso Sea]]'', which was published in October 1966, when she was 76.
[[Aron Ettore Schmitz]] published his first novel ''Senilità'' in his 38th year; however it was not until he published ''[[Zeno's Conscience]]'' that he made a breakthrough, aged 61. Even this was self-published.<ref>Furbank, Philip N., ''Italo Svevo: The Man and the Writer'' (1966)</ref>
In other areas of writing, historian [[Gerda Lerner]], born in 1920, published her first book, ''The Grimke Sisters from South Carolina,'' in 1967, when she was either 47 or 46 depending on her birthday.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/schlesinger-library/inside-the-collections/pioneer-in-womens-history-gerda-lerner|title=A Pioneer in Women’s History, Gerda Lerner (1920–2013)|publisher=|accessdate=29 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/books/9781469604879|title=Project MUSE - The Grimké Sisters from South Carolina|publisher=|accessdate=29 November 2014}}</ref> Poet [[Wallace Stevens]] started poetry late in life after years as an insurance salesman and executive. Although he was first published at 38, his "canonical works" came out in his fifties.<ref>Richardson, Joan. ''Wallace Stevens: The Early Years'', 1879–1923, New York: Beech Tree Books, 1986</ref> In philosophy [[Mary Midgley]] had her first book when she was 56.<ref>[http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/news/story/0,9830,1573651,00.html "Mary Midgley: Moral missionary"] ''The Guardian'', 20 September 2005. Retrieved 5 January 2009</ref> [[Edmond Hoyle]] wrote a booklet on [[whist]] in his late sixties. To avoid unauthorized copies he wrote the copyrighted ''A Short Treatise on the Game of Whist'' at age 70.<ref>[http://www.bookrags.com/biography/edmond-hoyle/ "Edmond Hoyle Biography"] ''Encyclopedia of World Biography''. Retrieved 5 January 2009</ref>
The Indian writer and polymath [[Nirad C. Chaudhuri]] wrote his autobiography ''[[The Autobiography of an Unknown Indian]]'' at the age of 54. He wrote a sequel to it ''[[Thy Hand, Great Anarch!]]'' at the age of 90. He published his next work (and his final work) ''Three Horsemen of the New Apocalypse'' at the age of 100.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sheren |first=Syeda Momtaz |year=2012 |chapter=Chaudhuri, Nirad C |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Chaudhuri,_Nirad_C |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}}</ref>
